qas.question: What animal was found with 17,000-year-old damage from tuberculosis?
During what time period do some scientist believe the first human could have contracted TB from an ancestor they shared with animals?
In which U.S. state was the oldest definitive evidence of TB found?
Which gene was concluded to come from animals?
What period did the bison live in?
What did animals get TB from?
What species have we definitively traced the origin of TB to?

context: Tuberculosis has been present in humans since antiquity. The earliest unambiguous detection of M. tuberculosis involves evidence of the disease in the remains of <a0_0>bison<a0_0/> in <a3_0>Wyoming<a3_0/> dated to around <b4_0>17,000 years ago<b4_0/>. However, whether tuberculosis originated in <b8_0>bovines<b8_0/>, then was transferred to humans, or whether it diverged from a common ancestor, is currently unclear. A comparison of the genes of <a1_0>M. tuberculosis complex<a1_0/> (MTBC) in humans to MTBC in animals suggests <b7_0>humans<b7_0/> did not acquire <b5_0>MTBC<b5_0/> from animals during animal domestication, as was previously believed. Both strains of the tuberculosis bacteria share a common ancestor, which could have infected humans as early as <b6_0>the <a2_0>Neolithic Revolution<b6_0/><a2_0/>.
